In an interview with NPR, Jerry Brown claimed that California's budget surplus was "up to $30 billion." A report by the Office of Non-Party Legislative Analysts expects the State to receive $14.5 billion in its Rene Day Reserve Fund by the end of next fiscal year. This would represent an increase over the $13.8 billion that the State expects to receive in that fund when the next fiscal year begins on 1 July 2019. The report also estimates that the legislature will receive $14.8 billion in estimated funds over the same period of time. Brown's description of the surplus "almost $30 billion" is generally correct, although it ignores the fact that this is the projection. Government finance experts pointed out that there were restrictions on Rene's money, a fact that Brown explained in the interview. They also note that California ' s surplus is expected to decrease in the coming years, with an economic slowdown expected. We found that Brown's statement was accurate but needed some clarification, most notably that the figure of $30 billion was a projection, not a certainty.
